title: Crested Gecko Temperature & Humidity Guide: Complete Climate Control
description: Complete temperature and humidity management guide for crested geckos covering thermal gradients, heating equipment, humidity maintenance, and troubleshooting climate issues.
author: Habitat Builder

content.title: Climate Requirements for Crested Geckos
content.content: Crested geckos are cool-temperature species from the cloud forests of New Caledonia, where temperatures are moderate year-round and humidity is consistently high. Unlike many reptiles, crested geckos do NOT require extreme heat and can actually suffer from overheating. This guide covers how to create appropriate thermal gradients and maintain the high humidity these arboreal geckos require.
Crested geckos need a subtle temperature gradient from warm (top) to cool (bottom). This gradient is naturally created in tall enclosures because heat rises.

content.text: Target Temperature Ranges:

rows: Top 6" of enclosure, directly under heat lamp

content.content: Temperatures above 85°F (29°C) are dangerous for crested geckos and can cause heat stress, regurgitation, or death. Avoid heat mats/tape—these create bottom heat that conflicts with natural thermoregulation (heat should come from above).
Crested geckos need minimal supplemental heating. Many temperate homes (70-75°F ambient) may not need heating at all except at the basking spot.

content.text: Heat Source Options:

rows: Intense focused heat, deeper light penetration
Gentle infrared heat, low fire risk

content.content: Never use heat mats, heat tape on the floor, or heated rocks. Crested geckos thermoregulate by moving vertically (up = warmer, down = cooler). Bottom heat creates confusion and doesn't mimic natural conditions.
Proper heat lamp placement creates a safe gradient while allowing the gecko to self-regulate body temperature.

content.text: Heat Lamp Configuration:

rows: Resting on screen top or suspended
Gecko can sleep here to absorb warmth
Turns heat lamp off at night (natural temp drop)

content.text: Adjusting Heat Output:

rows: Use dimmer to reduce power, OR switch to 25-30w bulb
Remove dimmer, OR switch to 50-60w bulb
Add secondary CHE for nighttime, insulate enclosure sides

content.content: Start with 40w and test for 48 hours before adjusting. A 40w bulb is sufficient for most 18×18×24 enclosures in rooms with 68-74°F ambient temperature. Only increase wattage if testing confirms basking zone stays below 80°F.
Accurate temperature measurement requires the right tools and understanding where to measure.

content.text: Thermometer Types & Uses:

rows: Spot-check basking area, branches, walls throughout enclosure
Track basking zone—place probe on basking branch
NOT RECOMMENDED—inaccurate, can't measure surface temps
Advanced: maintains exact temperature, cuts power when reached

content.text: Where to Measure Temperature:

rows: 1-2 hours after lights off to confirm drop

content.content: Measure temperature at the basking surface (where the gecko will rest), not in the open air. Air temperature is 5-10°F cooler than surface temperature under a heat lamp.
Crested geckos require high humidity for proper shedding, hydration, and respiratory health. Humidity should fluctuate naturally throughout the day.

content.text: Target Humidity Levels:

rows: Allows enclosure to breathe, prevents mold
Daily average balances hydration and drying

content.content: Constant 90%+ humidity without dry-out periods promotes bacterial/fungal growth and respiratory infections. Enclosures MUST dry to 50-60% between mistings to stay healthy.
Maintaining proper humidity requires the right substrate, misting schedule, and enclosure design.

content.text: Humidity Maintenance Methods:
Misting Protocol (Manual):

rows: All walls, plants, and décor (visible droplets)
Heavy misting—substrate should feel damp 1" down
Light mist on plants only, not substrate

content.content: Use tap water for misting, NOT distilled or reverse-osmosis water. Tap water contains minerals (calcium, magnesium) that benefit crested geckos. If your tap water is heavily chlorinated, let it sit 24 hours before misting.
Ambient room temperature and humidity change with seasons, requiring adjustments to heating and misting.

content.text: Seasonal Climate Management:

rows: Reduce heat lamp wattage or remove entirely if room >78°F; reduce misting to 1x daily
Increase heat lamp wattage; add CHE for nighttime; increase misting to 3x daily
Monitor daily, adjust dimmer as needed; standard 2x misting usually sufficient
Increase ventilation, reduce misting frequency, ensure substrate dries between sessions

content.text: Common Problems and Solutions:

rows: Gecko always on floor, gaping mouth, lethargy
Lower wattage, use dimmer, increase ventilation, relocate away from windows
Gecko inactive, not eating, dark coloration
Increase wattage to 50-60w, add CHE for nighttime, check room temperature
Stuck shed, sunken eyes, dry substrate
Increase misting to 3x daily, add live plants, increase substrate depth to 4"
Reduce misting to 1x daily, improve ventilation, decrease substrate moisture
Gecko seems uncomfortable, stays in one spot
Ensure heat lamp is on top only, verify cool zone is 10-15°F cooler than basking
Gecko very pale at night, not active at dusk
Add low-wattage CHE on timer (night only), insulate enclosure sides

content.content: Power outages, equipment failures, or extreme weather require emergency intervention to protect your gecko.

content.text: Emergency Interventions:

rows: Hand warmers wrapped in towel near (not in) enclosure, blanket over 3 sides
24-48 hours (crested geckos tolerate cold better than heat)
Move enclosure to coolest room, frozen water bottles outside enclosure, increase air flow
12-24 hours (heat is more dangerous than cold)
Temporary space heater in room (not enclosure), emergency bulb replacement
Remove all heat sources, relocate to air-conditioned room, ice packs outside enclosure
Manual misting 4x daily, damp towel over portion of screen top

content.content: If room temperature exceeds 85°F for more than 2-3 hours, move your crested gecko to the coolest room in your house or a basement. Prolonged exposure to temperatures above 88°F can be fatal.

content.text: Essential Climate Control Equipment:

content.content: Invest in quality thermometers and hygrometers—cheap analog stick-on gauges are inaccurate by 5-10°F and give false confidence. Etekcity 774 infrared gun ($15-20) and any digital probe thermometer ($10-15) are reliable budget options.
